titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Baba Freeman Reston, Virginia, collection 1966-2007

did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: George Mason University. Libraries. Special Collections & Archives.

did.abstract: This collection documents Baba Freeman's involvement in planning and transportation issues in the Reston, Virginia community.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Baba Freeman Reston, Virginia, C0267, Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University Libraries.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: There are no restrictions on personal use. Permission to publish material from the Baba Freeman Reston, Virginia, collection must be obtained from the Special Collections Research Center, George Mason University Libraries.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Special Collections and Archives holds many other collections on the history of Reston, Virginia.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing completed by Elizabeth Beckman in June 2015. EAD markup completed by Elizabeth Beckman in June 2015.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Baba Freeman (1927- ) and her husband Monroe moved their family to Reston in 1967, in the earliest days of the community's establishment. Freeman's involvement in all aspects of Reston area community affairs spanned the next several decades, and included roles in the Reston Citizen's Association, Reston youth athletics, Reston Interfaith, the Fairfax County League of Women Voters, and interest and involvement in transportation issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists largely of papers that document transportation and community issues in Reston, Virginia. There are documents pertaining to the Reston Citizens' Association, the Reston 2000 Task Force Committee, Reston Interfaith and various other community groups with which Baba Freeman was involved or associated, or in which she had an interest. Types of documents include correspondence, memos, meeting agendas, reports, newspaper articles, maps, planning and transportation studies, and a few photographs. The records cover much of Reston's history, from the initial Reston master plan from 1966 to the discussion of expanding Metro into Reston and beyond to Dulles International Airport in 2007.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in original order.

did.unittitle: An electronic box inventory is unavailable. Please contact speccoll@gmu.edu for more information.
